have your Home Office decision letter with you

homeOfficePage.title: What is your Home Office reference number?
homeOfficePage.description: You can find this on the top right-hand side of the decision letter.
homeOfficePage.refImageAltText: Image of Home Office decision letter

homeOfficeLetterSent.title: What date was the letter sent?
homeOfficeLetterSent.description: You can usually find this stamped on the envelope of the decision letter. If you don't have the envelope, you can enter the date on the first page of the decision letter.
homeOfficeLetterSent.letterSentImageAltText: Image of Home Office decision letter

homeOfficeAppealLate.title: Your appeal is late
homeOfficeAppealLate.description:
Appeals should be made within 14 days of the date the decision letter was sent.
You may still be able to appeal. Please tell us why your appeal is late, and provide supporting evidence if you have it.
homeOfficeAppealLate.provideEvidenceDescription: You can upload evidence to support your answer such as letters, photos and documents. If you are taking a picture of a letter, place it on a flat surface and take the picture from above.

successPage.title: Confirmation
successPage.info: You will receive a notification to confirm that the Tribunal has received your appeal details
successPage.noResponse: If you haven't heard from us by {{ date }} call 0300 123 1711 or send us a message
successPage.caseWorker: A Tribunal Caseworker will contact you to by {{ date }} to tell you if you can continue with your appeal and what to do next
successPage.tribunalWorker: A Tribunal Caseworker will contact you to by {{ date }} to tell you what to do next
successPage.readMore: Read more about appealing an immigration or asylum decision
successPage.findOutMore: Find organisations that can you with your appeal

outOfTime.panel: Your late appeal details have been sent

inTime.panel: Your appeal details has been sent

reasonForAppeal.title: Home Office Decision
reasonForAppeal.heading: Why do you think the Home Office decision is wrong?
reasonForAppeal.usefulInfo: It may be helpful to look at the Home Office documents (opens in a new window). They include your decision letter and other information about your case.
reasonForAppeal.textTitle: Tell us in your own words - you don't have to have perfect English.
reasonForAppeal.bulletOne: Carefully read your Home Office decision letter
reasonForAppeal.bulletTwo: Try to understand the parts of your claim the Home Office disagrees with
reasonForAppeal.bulletThree: Respond to some or all the things the Home Office disagrees with
reasonForAppeal.bulletFour: Tell us about anything new that will affect your case since you made your claim
reasonForAppeal.bulletFive: Include supporting evidence where you can. You can do this on the next page
reasonForAppeal.bulletLink: Find organisations that can help you with your appeal

caseBuildingSuccess.answer: A Tribunal Caseworker will look at your answer
caseBuildingSuccess.date: The Tribunal Caseworker will contact you by {{ date }} to tell you what to do next
caseBuildingSuccess.questions: If you have any questions about the appeal process, call the Tribunal on 0300 123 1711 or email customer.services@justice.gov.uk

reasonsForAppealUpload.title: Reasons Upload
reasonsForAppealUpload.heading: Providing supporting evidence
reasonsForAppealUpload.provideSupportingEvidenceQuestion: Do you want to provide supporting evidence?
reasonsForAppealUpload.uploadInfo: You can upload evidence to support your answer such as letters, photos and documents. If you are taking a picture of a letter, place it on a flat surface and take the picture from above.
reasonsForAppealUpload.findOutMore: Find out more about the evidence to support your appeal
reasonsForAppealUpload.evidence: If you want to provide evidence but don't have it right now, you can ask for more time

ineligiblePage.title: You cannot currently use the new appeal service
ineligiblePage.description: Based on your answers you can't use the new service at the moment. However, you can still appeal the Home Office decision either online or using our paper form
optionsList: Appeal by post or fax with form IAFT-5

moreInfo.title: More information
moreInfoList: Find out more about appealing an immigration or asylum decision

eligiblePage.title: Service Page
eligiblePage.heading: You can use the new appeal service
eligiblePage.basedOnAnswers: Based on your answers, you can use the new service to appeal an immigration or asylum decision.
eligiblePage.askQuestions: We will now ask you a few questions so you can send us your appeal details. You will first need to create an account, or sign in if you already have one.
eligiblePage.questions: If you have any questions about the appeal process, call the Tribunal on 0300 123 1711 or send us a message

appealStarted.fewQuestions: You need to answer a few questions about yourself and your appeal to get started.
appealStarted.finishQuestions: You need to finish telling us about your appeal.
appealStarted.needHomeOfficeDecision: You will need to have your Home Office decision letter with you to answer some questions.

appealSubmitted.detailsSent: Your appeal details have been sent to the Tribunal.
appealSubmitted.dueDate: A Tribunal Caseworker will contact you by {{ applicationNextStep.deadline }} to tell you what to do next.

eligibleStartPage.newService: This is a new online service for people appealing an immigration or asylum decision. Because it is a new service, not everyone will be able to use it right now.
eligibleStartPage.askQuestions: We need to ask you a few questions to see if the service is suitable for you.
eligibleStartPage.alreadyStarted: Have you already started an appeal?
eligibleStartPage.signIn: Sign in to continue with your appeal

caseWorker.title: What is a Tribunal Caseworker?
caseWorker.titleText: A Tribunal Caseworker manages immigration and asylum appeals to make sure everything is ready for a decision to be made about your appeal.

textAndBullets.title: A Tribunal Caseworker:
bullets: works with you and the Home Office to manage an appeal from start to finish
looks at any information you or the Home Office send the Tribunal
tells you or the Home Office what to do at each stage of the appeal and when it needs to be done by
tells you or the Home Office if there is anything you need to know about your appeal. For example, if you or the Home Office withdraws from the appeal
may decide to grant or refuse any applications you or the Home Office make to the Tribunal. For example, if you or the Home Office ask for more time
is not a Judge but does work closely with Judges
textAndBullets.desc: If you disagree with a decision a Tribunal Caseworker makes, you have 14 days to ask the Tribunal for a Judge to review the decision.

textAndBullets.smallTitle: What a Tribunal Caseworker can’t do
textAndBullets.title: A Tribunal Caseworker cannot:
bullets: go to a hearing with you
decide the outcome of your appeal

homeOfficeDocuments.title: Understanding your Home Office documents
homeOfficeDocuments.titleText: As part of the appeal process, the Home Office must send the Tribunal all the documents it has about your case. This is called the Home Office bundle.

textAndBullets.title: The Home Office bundle has two parts:
The cover letter is the first page of your bundle and contains:
bullets: your personal details and any Home Office or other reference numbers
a record of the decision to refuse your claim
your immigration history. For example, the date you arrived in the country, the date you made your claim and any other relevant dates
a list of the documents that are in the bundle and their page numbers. Details of the documents that might be in your bundle are in the next section
the date you decided to appeal

textAndBullets.title: Your bundle will include some or all of the following documents:
bulletsSpacing: Visa Application Form: If you made a Visa application, the application form and any evidence relevant to the decision to refuse you claim will be included in the bundle
Screening Interview: If you have claimed asylum, the Screening Interview is the first interview that takes place. The bundle will include a written record of the interview

Asylum Interview Record: If you have claimed asylum, the Asylum Interview (also known as the Asylum Substantive Interview) is when the Home Office asks you in detail about your reasons for claiming asylum. The bundle will include a written record of the interview

Documents submitted by appellant in support of claim: This is any supporting evidence that you gave to the Home Office as part of your claim. This could be a witness statement, medical records or official documents such as a birth certificate
Previous refusal: If you made a previous claim that was refused, any documents related to this claim will be included in the bundle
Previous appeal: If you made a previous appeal that was dismissed, any documents related to this appeal may be included in the bundle
Decision letter: This is the letter that explains why the Home Office refused your claim. A decision letter is sent to you by post and you should have a copy

textAndBullets.smallTitle: Where to find your Home Office bundle
textAndBullets.desc: Your Home Office bundle is accessible from the Overview page. Return to your Overview page and click Home Office documents about your case to access your Home Office bundle.
If you need help understanding your Home Office documents, you can call 0300 123 1711 or email customer.service@justice.gov.uk

helpWithAppeal.title: Get help with your appeal
helpWithAppeal.titleText: There are a number of ways to get advice on appealing an asylum or immigration decision.

textAndBullets.title: Get advice over the phone on the asylum process, including appealing an asylum decision.
Find registered immigration advisers in your area who may be able to help with your appeal.
Legal aid can help pay for legal advice. Check if you qualify for legal aid.
textAndBullets.text: If you do qualify, you can search for a legal adviser with a legal aid contract in England and Wales.

textAndBullets.title: Get free, confidential help from your local Citizens Advice on a range of immigration issues. Please note that Citizens Advice does not currently offer advice on asylum issues.

evidenceToSupportAppeal.title: Evidence to support your appeal
evidenceToSupportAppeal.titleText: Evidence is any information that supports your appeal.

textAndBullets.title: Anything you tell the Tribunal is evidence. It is likely to help your case if you can provide further relevant evidence to prove what you say is true. For example, if you tell the Tribunal you are a citizen of a particular country, a copy of your passport is further evidence that this is true.
textAndBullets.desc: Here are some examples of different kinds of evidence that could support your appeal.

textAndBullets.title: A witness is someone who comes to a hearing to speak on your behalf. This is known as oral evidence. A witness could be:
bullets: anybody who knows something relevant about your case
textAndBullets.desc: All witnesses must write a witness statement, which is a written version of their oral evidence. The witness statement should include the appeal reference number as well as the witness’ address, date of birth, signature and photo identification.

textAndBullets.title: A letter of support is usually written by someone who knows you well such as a friend or family member. The letter normally explains how the writer knows you and describes what kind of person they think you are.
textAndBullets.text: A letter of support should include the appeal reference number as well as the supporter’s address, date of birth, signature and photo identification.

textAndBullets.title: You can use information or reports about a country to support anything you have said about that country in your appeal. Examples include:
bullets: official country reports (for example, Home Office or US State Department country reports)
country expert reports (for example, from an academic specialising in that country)
cases the Tribunal has already heard about your country

textAndBullets.title: There are a number of ways you can show your connection to a particular group or involvement in public demonstrations. Examples include:
You may need evidence to prove your relationship with a child, spouse or other family member. Examples include:
You may need evidence for any physical or mental health conditions you want to tell the Tribunal about. Examples include:
You may need evidence to show if you have been arrested or involved in any criminal activity that is relevant to your appeal. This could be from your home country or the UK. Examples include:
bullets: first instance reports, if your case refers to alleged criminal activity in your home country

textAndBullets.title: You may need to provide official documents to prove your nationality or family relationships. Examples include:
You may need to provide evidence to prove your financial situation. Examples include:
bullets: no recourse to public funds/local authority letters

textAndBullets.title: You may need to provide evidence of any courses you have taken and awards you have received. Examples include:
It may be helpful to use legal arguments and documents to support your appeal. Examples include:
bullets: decisions of cases linked to yours (for example, a family member or someone in a similar situation)
decisions of cases from your home country

contactUs.heading: Contact us for help

Ask a question or get help in your language.

Telephone: 0300 123 1711

Email: customer.service@justice.gov.uk

Monday to Friday, 8:30am to 5pm

Find out about call charges

contactUsErrorPages.linesOpeningTimes: Lines open Monday to Friday 8.30am to 5pm

protection.name: Protection
protection.title: Protection (You will be persecuted or harmed in some way if you are returned to your home country)
protection.examples: You might be afraid of the government, police or other groups in your home country because of your nationality, race, religion, political opinion or other reason.

revocationOfProtection.name: Revocation of Protection Status
revocationOfProtection.title: Revocation of Protection Status (Your protection status was taken away)
revocationOfProtection.examples: Your protection status might have been taken away if it is believed you no longer need it, you didn’t tell the truth in your claim or you have committed a serious crime.

eligibility.question: Are you at least 18 years old?
eligibility.errorMessage: Select yes if you are at least 18 years old

eligibility.question: Are you currently living in England or Wales?
eligibility.errorMessage: Select yes if you are currently living in England or Wales

eligibility.question: Are you currently in detention?
eligibility.description: This could be a prison or an immigration removal centre.
eligibility.errorMessage: Select yes if you are currently in detention

eligibility.question: Are you appealing an Asylum and/or Humanitarian Protection decision?
eligibility.description: You should answer yes if you fear you will be persecuted or harmed in some way if you are sent back to your home country.
eligibility.errorMessage: Select yes if you are appealing an Asylum and/or Humanitarian Protection decision

eligibility.question: Is anyone else in your immediate family appealing their own Home Office decision?
eligibility.errorMessage: Select yes if anyone in your immediate family is appealing their own Home Office decision
